Rather they see a crisis in systematic biology because hypotheses of relationships based on molecular data are often not grounded in thorough (or even cursory) morphological analyses and clades lacking morphological synapomorphies are routinely proposed. Rather than viewing this lack of morphological character support for hypothesized clades as a crisis, I see it as a growing pain of the science. In time, if we continue to train and adequately support students of morphology (an uncertain prospect to be sure), the molecular hypotheses will for the most part have their day in the court of morphology.

Rather than critique the many points raised by
, a task left to others in this volume, I wish to present my own views, similar to those of
, that morphological and molecular data should be viewed as complementary, each providing potentially novel insights, and that practitioners of both should be knowledgeable of the methods and welcome the results of the other. Coming as I do from a morphologist’s background, I illustrate two examples in which molecular data can inform morphology, namely that molecular analyses can guide a posteriori examination of morphology, renewing the search for morphological synapomorphies, and genetic data can relatively easily identify “cryptic” variation that has been overlooked by morphologists.

sec.title: Novel relationships suggested by molecular data
sec.p:
Ekemblemaria
is a curious genus of only three species of tube blennies ( Teleostei, Blennioidei , Chaenopsidae ). John Stephens, who described the genus in 1963, hypothesized its relationships with
Acanthemblemaria
(1963, 1970), an hypothesis later supported by three morphological synapomorphies (
,
). However, recent phylogenetic analysis of one mitochrondial and four nuclear genes totaling 3,544 base pairs, surprisingly placed
Ekemblemaria
with the wrasse blenny,
Hemiemblemaria simulus
, with strong statistical support in Bayesian, maximum likelihood and parsimony analyses (Lin, 2009;
). Inclusion of a data matrix of 148 morphological characters, including the three putative synapomorphies of
Ekemblemaria
and
Acanthemblemaria
, in a “total evidence” analysis did not change the result. The molecular signal out-weighed the signal in the morphological data.

This new and unanticipated hypothesis of relationships stimulated a search for corroborating morphological support. Subsequent examination revealed two novel morphological synapomorphies for
Ekemblemaria
and
Hemiemblemaria
and two others that were in the original morphological data set but assumed to be homoplasious (
. In this case, the detailed and highly sophisticated statistical analyses of molecular data stimulated a successful search for supporting morphological evidence (synapomorphies).

sec.title: Cryptic diversity
sec.p: Rather than fearing that our science is taking a turn for the worse and bemoaning the inevitable march of molecular biology into systematic biology, I suggest that all systematists embrace new analytical methods and new data sets to inform and guide their own research while remaining grounded in the scientific tradition that they know best. I too am sometimes frustrated when envisioning, studying and teaching about clades without known morphological synapomorphies. But I am also excited by the fresh hypotheses and refinements of long-standing ideas of relationships that molecular data inevitably bring. Our science will be best served when we fully embrace new data sources and refined analytical methods and incorporate them with more traditional methods to gain an ever-clearer picture of the tree of life.
